it's for um it's to you know to develop the technology space for our cities and
our government but I'm kind of curious you know is it a startup is it what is the makeup of code for America yeah I
mean we're we're structured around a fellowship program and uh what that means is that every year for the entire
calendar year we have a class of 25 to 30 fellows who join us um these are
people who apply to join us they go through a fairly rigorous selection process like Ezra did um and they come
to us as designers they come to us as developers urban planners and other professions uh typically you know kind
of in the middle to early part of their careers looking to make a change or transition into government um on the
other side we work with cities who also apply to be code for America cities uh
this year we have a mix of nine cities and counties including New York City um Oakland California uh Louisville
Kentucky Summit County Ohio and a few others um and they come to us with very specific problems you know some of them
want to work on uh things like criminal justice others want to work on economic development still others want to work on
food availability and um food banks and things like that um and essentially we create kind of a design Camp design
process built around this where for 11 months out of the year the fellows and cities work together to create a
response to some sort of problem that the city is experiencing that could use a technical solution so how many cities
you usually apply each year uh you know I'm actually not sure I want to say that it's something like 20 or 30 this year
um we're currently in the process of narrowing down our selection for the 2014 cities and I think we have it down
to a list of something like 10 or so finalists um and so they they come to you each year basically with a problem
set maybe before the fellowship begins and part of the fellowship this 11 month program is about tackling and solving
some of those problems yeah we try to frame the problems in a somewhat General way um so for example a city may want to
work on you know economic development but that doesn't mean that they're coming to us with a specific application
that they want build we're not like a vendor uh or a Contracting agency uh we
work with the cities to figure out what the real nut of the problem is um and
then develop Solutions based on Research that gets performed early on in the fellowship so does one Fellowship from
one year to another kind of piggy back off of one other's work like did does last year program kind of bleed into this year's
program and then then then you know on and down the line uh in many cases yeah
the fellowships themselves will end at the end of the year um and then some people will stay on in other positions
so for example we have uh two folks from last year um who stayed on as a designer
in Residence and an engineer in Residence after completing their Fellowship um and in some cases like for
example with Philadelphia cities will come back for a second opportunity to work with us um generally speaking the
way that the fellowship and you know the years feed into each other is through our very extensive GitHub repository of
projects uh and through the startups and additional projects that fellows go on to do with their work after they're
finished with the fellowship that's pretty cool so um let's let's talk about um I guess one of
the topics that you'd mentioned we had a kind of a preall you talked a lot about um your desire to talk about technical
sustainability um as it relates to the different challenges you guys are
helping cities that apply to code for America to solve um you know what is some of the number one challenges that
cities are I guess facing with technical sustainability yeah I think that there's really kind of a broad set of challenges
that cities are facing but the two top ones probably are um different expectations around technology um and
then also different expectations around things like budget and how much things
cost uh so in terms of expectations around technology you know as you might imagine uh the people who join us from
industry as fellows are frequently working with application Stacks like you know python or Ruby on Rails or node.js
you know fairly new fairly modern Technologies while on the flip side City it departments tend to be composed of
much older Technologies so they might be exclusively Microsoft shops um or they might require that things be built on an
Oracle database and so forth and so there's a huge sustainability challenge in figuring out how to kind of draw
those two worlds together and make sure that the kind of Open Source methodologies that we use for all of our
work uh can be adequately reflected in the environments that cities are deploying in you mentioned uh your

reshape uh ideas for city government uh it's been colossal I mean we have
projects from our very first year of Fellowship back in 2011 that are still being worked on and extended and

entire Fellowship cool you mentioned um people that uh
join or you know apply to to be a fellow for this 11 month program that they're either wanting to make change or get

uh blight monitoring in New Orleans or text messaging in the case of texasin uh
and have turned those things into startups with like actual revenu and and business expectations around them uh in
other cases we've seen fellows move on to open- Source companies and other technology companies uh one of our

have gone out companies like Airbnb I think uh Google might be one of them so people go on to do a lot of interesting
stuff from here that's cool I wanted to ask how do the projects actually get
like selected and and who which fellows work on them and like what does that process look like in house yeah so I
mean Ezra you're actually in the midst of the fellowship do you want to maybe talk about it sure yeah so um you know
the application process I'm going to put a quick plug out here early at at the beginning of the show saying that we're actually looking for fellows for next
year right now the applications are due at the end of the month on the 31st code for america.org apply um but fellows come from a variety
of backgrounds um we have folks who are you know hardcore software you know frontend backend developers we have
folks who are coming more from a design side or more from government side and the way that our teams are formed they're sort of cross disciplinary we
have uh you know my team has two developers and one designer on it and um we sort of knew coming in um that we
were assigned to New York City which is where I'm working and we knew that our project Focus was going to be criminal
justice and in particular we were looking at a particular part of Criminal Justice the time between when a person
is arrested and when they're sentenced um there's some basically some new Theory saying that these are this is
sort of the time um within the criminal justice system where we can really have the chance to help people uh stay out of
trouble in the future and knowing that um we sort of all came here in in January when the fellowship started um
and the process begins with a sort of month-long training process since we all come from so many different backgrounds
and a lot of us haven't actually worked in government before it's sort of like a month-long crash course in how
government works how open source Works um different strategies that have worked and haven't worked in trying to engage
with governments we even had a dayong uh negotiation training which sounds like sort of a weird thing but um it really
gave our teams uh a good ability to learn how to like talk to people and we're sort of realizing you know we talk
about open source you know in this community like it's sort of just something we know is good but when you're talking with folks that maybe
aren't as familiar with it or or see it maybe even as as something that's threatening the way they do their work
um you need to be really cognizant of where they're coming from and how to sort of talk to them and really understand them so that so that you're
not actually just just being rude or dismissive of the kinds of needs they have um but in terms of your question of
you know how do actually projects get selected um after a month-long training the three you know team members for New
York and and the uh 20 27 fellows this year who are working with nine different cities and counties basically did a
month-long inter intensive residency where we flew out to our cities uh we lived there we lived all together in in
houses in each in our each of our cities and uh basically did a month of interviews where we talked with people
that work in the city Citizens Community groups in our case uh since we were focused on criminal justice we were
talking to uh judges and people in courtrooms and lawyers and those sorts of folks that try to ask the question
what's broken um what's not working what could be better and from there we sort
of used a collaborative process of of deciding you know what problem we want to tackle and what apps we want to build
this is really different by the way from from the way that most governments work with technology most of the time
um there's some need that people sort of see let's say it's you know driver's
licensing um you know data management or something and then they'll issue a you know RFP a request for proposals and
vendors will bid on those proposals and then they'll they'll choose someone that that builds the application to a you
know potentially enormous spec for a potentially large amount of money and we're sort of trying to demonstrate that
we can look at problems from the ground up use sort of this um agile um idea not
just in software development of problem solving starting with something small building something uh and testing it uh
to try to solve a small problem and then building off of it um and expanding it to to to fill other things as well so
it's sort of a new idea um with a lot of governments but folks are starting to get pretty excited about
it I'm kind of curious about uh I guess City collaboration you know when I think about you mentioned um you know driver's
license and and data sets and stuff like that around that and different applications that might make sense um at
what point do cities begin to speak at the government level around technology is there some sort of um I mean is that
what our national government helps to accomplish or is it up to the cities and individual states to help kind of lift
those cities up and speak to one another to maybe have a unified system for dealing with driver's license for
example well I think it's sort of a mix um you know think about it this way if you're working at a startup or any other
company who's going to make the decisions about technology it'll be the people there it won't necessarily be
anyone telling you what to do there though you might have a sense of of what the best practices are in your particular field or industry and I think
in government it's largely the same um but because of the way that procurement
that's the way that you know go government entities select vendors to build software but because of the way
that works um often times cities and counties and states and the federal government are sort of going it alone
and um looking for products that meet their needs um from the open source world we know there's this this huge
advantage of actually collaborating to solve problems and to build something together but uh in the government world
that's uh a little bit more rare and that's one of the things that we're trying to do at code for America is by working across multiple cities and
counties and States at once we can sort of start to see those um similar
problems emerge and then find ways to bring people together to look at them
together what kind of a response do you do you tend to get from the cities themselves like are they interested
excited or you know what kind of response do you get when you're actually talking with the government of the
cities that you're going to be working with in your experience Ezra well I think um I think you'll have a a sort of
a multitude of responses and it depends on sort of who you're talking to and why because remember City governments are not unified we're talking of especially
in the case of New York City is thousands and thousands of people all with different roles and and different different needs that they have to do for
their work um I think most of our our cities we partner with our ecstatic to
be uh participants in the code for America fellowship program and the other programs we have because they see us as
a as a way they can do their work better uh they have uh things they do whether
it's you know driver's licensing or uh you know having a police force or any of those other services that that we think
of when we think of government um but they never have enough resources to be able to do everything they possibly want to do and they see technology and
particularly you know our our kind of Open Source technology as a way of doing better work maybe for less money and and
that's awesome when it gets to actually building software though it's a little bit more complicated as Mike was saying
earlier you know folks that run it departments have particular methodologies and stacks and things
they're they're really comfortable with and sometimes us coming in there uh shakes the uh uh shakes things up a
little bit but uh because we're sort of engaged usually at a a higher level on
the the political side but also um also working with people who are doing their day-to-day work were usually able to uh
to make things work right now um working with New York I'm in the middle of a uh
it process we trying to get servers provisioned and trying to get Linux set up and all that sort of good stuff and
I'm used to in my normal life just firing up Heroku or getting an ec2 instance or doing what it takes myself

and we've right this year we're working with nine different cities and counties across the United States from New York
where I am to San Francisco Oakland Las Vegas Summit County Ohio which is the county around acon we're working in a
ton of different places and as as Mike was saying each one of these governments has sort of Chosen One topic that they
want uh us to work on for the year um the way that our Partnerships work is we generally have one or two
Primary people within the city government who are serve as our main contacts and sort of our Liaisons um
usually one of them is working in the topic area that we're working in so in the case of uh Summit County there doing
a project related to Parks so they have they have folks in the parks there that they're working with primarily um but
then they also have contacts in the it or technology Departments of those cities as well so we have sort of a

about criminal justice it is so complicated it's especially mean it's especially complicated as a uh person
with no background in that system but even I think for lawyers and other other people it's it's pretty complicated and
our main contact has been working as a lawyer for many years in New York City he understands the system really well
he's he's been a defense attorney he's worked for the government and he knows everybody and so working with him and
with some of our other friends we were able to set up meetings with people all across the system so you know police uh
courts um uh probation you know District Attorneys
all the sort of players that are involved in the process and and and then you know by talking with each of them we can start to get a sense of uh of what's
going on so what projects specifically have you been working on in in terms of
Open Source with uh New York so we're still sort of uh figuring out what

year overy year has kind of afforded you that that ability too
yeah I think so I mean you know obviously I'm new here but I've also really had a nice vantage point over the

and so we almost become kind of like a I don't know like a cut across an organization in a way yeah it's cool

go sports here but um you know during the during the last you know 15 years of

early on in the fellowship uh and then sort of iterating on that and working on

viable product it you know it almost seems like if we can get people in the government people in you know the public

Linux versus Windows versus rails versus python all that usual kind of stuff um
and then also the kind of political and emotional and human environment that that that lives inside of you know so
one of the things that I'm looking at in the cities that we're working with is what actually happens to this code

or and gigantic Java base systems you know very classic kind of big ass it

social environment of where you deploy too and so what are the what are some of the I guess hurdles you've been able to

the biggest hurdle that we're staring down the barrel of right now is that the you know 2013 is a very challenging

to some cities that have literally Z training budgets for their it staffs I
talk to other cities that have no it staff whatsoever you know just sort of enthusiastic people that want to help

you know how do you transfer some of what we've seen in the open source and startup

where they're perhaps used to buying hardware and provisioning racked services and you know paying a lot more

type of Technology deployment if they're dealing with very very challenging budget situations you mentioned budget
there and it's it kind of bleeds into the other topic we want to talk about too which is um the skill Gap I guess

uh Andrew mentioned you see more of on on GitHub these days or in open source that people are using and forking and
modifying and changing rapidly versus older Technologies and some of the more modern development tools what's the the
Gap happening there for cities well I think one of the challenges is that um when you're
working for a government um I think oftentimes it's easy to become really risk averse because you hear all these
sort of stories in the news about government spending too much time working on something or or spending too much money and um so when when you're in
that sort of environment you use what you know and it's hard to blame anybody for doing that you don't want to you don't want to get in trouble so um I

lend itself well to a more rapidly paced uh maybe open- source-based software
environment because it just it takes longer for things to filter down um I think in in many cases people are

WordPress on my server I would want to you know hire someone to start and manage the servers that my WordPress

before there just isn't a whole lot of budgets for capacity building and for training within it departments as well
so it's a uh it's a tough it's a tough situation it is a tough situation I mean
